Chapter 1 - On-the-job safety measures

Overview:
Purpose: Safety is a shared responsibility among all workers in every trade. Gas technicians/fitters frequently work in potentially dangerous situations with equipment that can cause injury to both themselves and others. Consequently, you must be thoroughly familiar with the hazards you may face, and the safety procedures relevant to work habits, specific work sites, and tools and equipment.

Objectives:
At the end of this Chapter, you will be able to:
• describe personal safety factors;
• describe site hazards and protections;
• describe the safety features of tools and equipment; and
• describe general safe work habits.

Terminology:
- Confined space: An area in which location, design, or construction restricts entry and exit. In a confined space, there may be work, an atmosphere, operations, or equipment that is hazardous to health and safety.
- Group safety equipment: Equipment supplied by an employer that is positioned around a job site (e.g., fire extinguishers and a first aid kit)
- Lockout procedures: Procedures that involve the use of locks and safety tags to ensure the isolation and "lock-off" of all sources of potential, kinetic, and stored energy
- Musculoskeletal disorder hazards (MSDs): An aspect of a job or process that increases the risk of a worker developing an MSD disorder (The primary MSD hazards are related to force, posture, and repetition)
- Personal protective equipment (PPE): Standard safety equipment (includes clothing)
- Ventilation equipment: Equipment designed to remove harmful dust or fumes

Personal safety:
Personal safety is a combination of knowledge and awareness. A gas technician/fitter must be knowledgeable and skillful in the use and care of tools and must be aware of the hazards and safety procedures that apply to a job or on a job site. Safe work practices are as important as trade skills, forming the basis of all workplace safety rules.

Consider these factors in relation to personal safety:
• Work habits
• MSD hazards
• Clothing
• Protective equipment

Work habits:
A competent worker masters skills to the point where they become second nature. Skilled workers perform their tasks safely and correctly while always being mindful of how their actions may impact the safety of others.

By adopting the following behaviours, you will become a safer person to work with:
- Courtesy: Courtesy means taking into account the safety of those you are working with. Put yourself in the other person's shoes and always keep them in mind. (When you recognize a hazard, it is your responsibility to correct it or clearly identify it. Never assume that it is someone else's job.)
- Attention: To avoid accidents, pay attention to your environment and the people around you.
- Safe conduct: Safe conduct involves wearing appropriate clothing, using protective equipment, observing good housekeeping and safety procedures, and exercising common sense. Safe conduct also involves following correct procedures in the event of an accident.

MSD hazards and disorders:
Many jobs have aspects that increase the risk of a worker developing an MSD. While other factors can also increase the risk of MSD, the primary MSD hazards are force, posture (e.g., fixed or awkward postures), and repetition.

MSD Hazard Details:
1. Force: All work tasks require workers to use their muscles to exert some level of force. However, when a task requires someone to exert a level of force that is too high for any particular muscle, it can damage the muscle or the related tendons, joints, and other soft tissue.

2. Posture: Posture refers to the relative position of various parts of the body. For most joints, a good or "neutral" posture means that the joints are being used near the middle of their full range of motion.

3. Repetition: The risk of developing an MSD increases when the same parts of the body are used repeatedly, especially when there are also few breaks or chances to rest.

Additional MSD hazards and factors in the workplace include: contact stress, vibration (local impact or impact to hand/arm or whole body), cold or hot temperatures/environments, repeated impact, and poor work organization or methods.

Protective Equipment:
Standard safety clothing (including eye protection and safety footwear) is usually mandatory, but some sites or employers may require you to use additional PPE (e.g., high-visibility clothing). Specifically, you must have equipment to protect your head, lungs, eyes/sight, hands, feet, and ears/hearing.

Head protection (CSA Z94.1 - Class E, Type I or Type II):
Regulatory authorities and employers may require employees to wear hard hats and other accessories in specific areas, to suit specific job conditions. Most head protection is adjustable, and some have chin straps, liners, and earmuffs. Regulations prohibit employees from altering a hard hat in any way including painting, applying stickers, or drilling holes.

Respiratory (lung) protection (CSA Z94.2 and CSA Z180.1):
A gas technician/fitter may be exposed to airborne particles, chemicals, toxic gases, and fumes that can cause lung damage when inhaled. In situations that involve exposure to such substances, use an approved mask or respirator.

Eye and face protection (CSA Z94.3, CSA Z94.3.1, and CSA Z462):
Eye protection is a critical safety concern for workers on a job site. Workers must wear appropriate eye and face protection suited to their work conditions and the tasks being performed.

Hearing protection (CSA Z94.2):
Many work environments require specific hearing protection. Noise can affect you in several ways: moderate noise levels over a long period can diminish your ability to hear certain types of sounds, high noise levels can impair your hearing, and high noise levels can affect your mental state.

Hand protection (CSA Z462 for electrically rated protection):
Statistics show that approximately 30% of work-related injuries involve a worker's fingers, hands, or arms. Different types of gloves for different purposes: rubber/plastic for chemicals, thermally insulated for hot/cold, gauntlet-type welding gloves, leather/vinyl-coated for handling materials, certified rubber gloves for electrical work.

Foot protection (CSA Z195):
A gas technician/fitter's working environment requires Grade 1 footwear that complies with CSA Z195. Compliance is indicated by a green equilateral triangle with sides measuring approximately 25 mm (1 in) sewn or otherwise permanently attached to the right shoe upper.

Site hazards and protections:
A gas technician/fitter works in various capacities across a number of different environments, potentially encountering site-specific work hazards. You must be able to identify hazards and take precautionary measures to protect yourself and others from harm.

Physical hazards commonly encountered:
- Working in restricted spaces or cramped work areas
- Difficulty gaining access to equipment or appliances
- Exposure to corrosive residues
- Equipment or appliances that are moving (or non-fixed)
- Electrical hazards
- Movement of liquids or solids (in pipes, tubes, or other vessels)
- Extreme temperatures

Confined spaces:
A confined space is an area in which location, design, or construction restrict entry and exit. Before engaging in any work within a confined space, you will usually undergo training and certification that is site and situation specific.

Ladder safety:
Ladders are essential tools but can be dangerous if used improperly. Key precautions include checking for defects, ensuring proper positioning (4:1 ratio), securing the base, maintaining three points of contact, and avoiding electrical hazards.

Chapter 2 - Government acts and regulations

Overview:
Purpose: Government acts and regulations outline workplace requirements, many of which directly impact the work of a gas technician/fitter. Each province and territory has its own specific acts and regulations that cover safety requirements related to the handling and storage of fuels, fire prevention, work practices, the certification and licensing of tradespersons, etc.

Objective:
At the end of this Chapter, you will be able to describe the relevant sections of OHS acts and regulations in different provincial jurisdictions.

Terminology:
- Act: A legal document that defines the powers of directors, inspectors, etc. An act enables the government to write regulations.
- Regulation: A legal directive created under the authority of an act to address specific areas and provide detailed requirements and guidelines.
- Workers' Compensation Board (WCB): An agency responsible for workers' compensation in federal, provincial, or territorial jurisdictions.

Occupational health and safety acts and regulations:
OHS requirements are governed by provincial and territorial jurisdictions. Most provinces and territories have legislation in the form of regulations and acts dealing with OHS (e.g., OHSA).

Acts:
Acts are legal documents that define the powers of directors, inspectors, etc.; they also enable the government to write regulations. A provincial or territorial act that deals with OHS will contain sections on topics such as: application, administration, and enforcement of the act; duties of employers, employees, and others; right to refuse or stop work when health or safety are in danger; employer reprisals; toxic substances; notices; offences; penalties; appeals; and regulations.

Regulations:
Regulations are legal directives that address specific areas and provide detailed requirements and guidelines. Typically, regulations fall under OHS or WCA, while others are based on energy, fuel, or gas safety acts.

Example regulation requirements:
If a gas technician/fitter finds an unacceptable condition or immediate hazard when working with gas, they must:
• immediately shut off the gas supply to the appliance or work;
• immediately give verbal notice of their actions to the gas distributor;
• immediately give the appliance user written notice describing the condition and direction that the appliance not be used until rectified;
• give written notice of the condition to the distributor within 14 days.

Reporting requirements for workers' compensation:
In Canada, every worker has the right to a safe workplace. Provincial requirements mandate that hazards be reported within a specific timeframe. Employers must complete paperwork from the relevant provincial body whenever an employee sustains a work-related injury or contracts an occupational disease.

Chapter 4 - Fire safety practices

[Chapter 4 full content provided by user - showing abbreviated version]

Overview:
A gas technician/fitter is often exposed to hazardous materials that are flammable and potentially explosive. Understanding preventive safety measures and knowing how to handle different types of fires can help avoid serious injury and property damage.

Combustion triangle components:
1. Fuel - combustible material
2. Heat (ignition) - sufficient temperature
3. Oxygen - usually from air
4. Uninhibited chemical reaction

Fire Classes and Extinguishers:
- Class A (Green triangle): Ordinary combustibles (wood, cloth, paper, rubber, plastics)
- Class B (Red square): Flammable or combustible vapours
- Class C (Blue circle): Energized electrical equipment
- Class D (Yellow star): Combustible metals (magnesium, titanium, zirconium, sodium, potassium)
- Class K (Black hexagon): Vegetable oils, animal oils, or fats in cooking appliances

ULC Ratings:
Class A: Water equivalency (1A = 1.25 gallons)
Class B: Square footage coverage
Class C: No size rating, sufficient for electrical conditions
Class D: Generally no numerical rating
Class K: No numerical rating

flammable or potentially explosive. Knowing what preventive measures to 
take and how to deal with different types of fires will help gas 
technicians/fitters and the workers around them to avoid serious injury or 
property damage.

Understanding Fire
Fire is the rapid oxidation of a flammable material in the chemical 
process of combustion, releasing heat, light, and various reaction 
products. Oxidation is defined as the union of a substance with oxygen.
Oxidation takes place at varying rates, from very slow processes like 
rusting iron to extremely fast reactions like exploding gunpowder.
The rate of oxidation determines whether a process is considered a fire. 
While slow oxidation like rusting is not a fire, fast oxidation like burning 
paper or wood is classified as fire.

The Combustion Triangle
The combustion triangle illustrates the three elements needed 
for fire: fuel, heat, and oxygen. When these three elements 
combine, fire can occur.
The advanced combustion tetrahedron adds a fourth element: 
the uninhibited chemical reaction. This model provides a more

Class K fires involve vegetable oils, animal oils, or fats in cooking

kitchens where they can spread quickly and are difficult to

14. Class K Fire Extinguisher Selection: You should use the Class K (wet chemical) 
extinguisher. This fire involves cooking oils and fats in a commercial kitchen setting, which is 
specifically a Class K fire. The Class K extinguisher dispenses a fine mist that doesn't splash 
blazing oil and contains potassium acetate that reacts with the oils to form a foam blanket that 
smothers the fire. Using a Class A (water) extinguisher would be extremely dangerous as water 
and hot oil don't mix and could cause the fire to spread violently. A Class B extinguisher might 
work temporarily but is not designed for the specific chemistry of cooking oils and would not 
provide the long-term suppression needed.

and Class C (energized electrical equipment) fires. Step-by-step approach:
